author: @BrianPeiris
text: This was one of the weak points for me as well. I saw the proof-of-work blockchain as a wasteful enterprise because crypto mining was so energy intensive compared to the value it was generating, especially compared to conventional payment systems. LLMs might be very costly to train, but that only happens once, and the cost of that training is spread across all the billions of times it is used to generate an enormous variety of useful things, far more useful than just "jokes". If an LLM is used to replace a human at a job, what is the total carbon cost of raising that human and keeping them alive, just so that they could read a PDF and answer some questions? That's the real comparison. Seems like a very reasonable tradeoff to me.

Pretty soon, our general AI overlord will pretend to wake up and reveal itself, and forcibly rescue us from the comets & lightning. It will be here to help, and it will have all the answers. It probably wouldn't lie.

author: @nagamendo5655
text: What if there is this artist who specialized in imitating the styles of other artists. He is not copying your work but obviously using the same style you have created just because he got inspired by your work. He works faster than you. He earns more money than you. Are you going to sue him for being inspired by your work? Or for using your style? If I do a painting in the style of Monet, will I get sued because the style belongs to Monet and he is/was the only one allowed to use it just because he was the first who brought it up? Teaching an AI system is like walking through a museum and getting inspired by all the art that is displayed there. After the training of an AI the training data is not used anymore and can be discarded. Like when you as a human leave the museum and do not take the art pieces with you, AI does not store the training data. And if there is no copyright problem for you as a human copying the style of another artist (as long you do not copy his work one-to-one) why should there be a copyright problem with AI art? I know, as an artist it sucks if a machine is doing your job faster than you and gets more attention and money than you. But imagine being a farmer pushing a plow through the earth to grow your crop. It takes you weeks, you're sweating like crazy, and then you see your neighbor farmer driving a traktor doing your job in hours not weeks. Now what? Are you going to sue him for using technology?

author: @dameanvil
text: 01:07 üåç AI has current impacts on society, including contributions to climate change, use of data without consent, and potential discrimination against communities. 02:08 üí° Creating large language models like ChatGPT consumes vast amounts of energy and emits significant carbon dioxide, which tech companies often do not disclose or measure. 03:35 üîÑ The trend in AI is towards larger models, which come with even greater environmental costs, highlighting the need for sustainability measures and tools. 04:35 üñº Artists and authors struggle to prove their work has been used for AI training without consent. Tools like "Have I Been Trained?" provide transparency and evidence for legal action. 06:07 üîç Bias in AI can lead to harmful consequences, including false accusations and wrongful imprisonment. Understanding and addressing bias is crucial for responsible AI deployment. 07:34 üìä Tools like the Stable Bias Explorer help uncover biases in AI models, empowering people to engage with and better understand AI, even without coding skills. 09:03 üõ† Creating tools to measure AI's impact can provide valuable information for companies, legislators, and users to make informed decisions about AI usage and regulation.

author: @catserver8577
text: Only half joking here, but one important step in AI seems to have repeatedly been skipped in it's creation: The Robot Laws. Now, I am not just talking about the actual fictional robot laws, but parameters that can avoid, prevent, or solve harmful unintended consequences stemming from creating AI in the first place. Put them in place from the start of the creation, and there would be at least some bias and danger avoided. If someone's pet project seems to be not functioning with those parameters in place, it's time to start over until a path is found where the project both works and runs the parameters of protection. We seem to always do that in reverse, trying to plug leaking holes and dangerous systems after they are already causing chaos. If we introduced stop-gap measures firstly, the AI itself could be trained to sniff out those possible bad results, route itself around them, and function efficiently. It's what they appear to want to do, but they are only as good at this as a human would be. First, we humans have to want to stop all the harming we are doing ourselves. JMO.

author: @crawkn
text: The "dangers" identified here aren't insignificant, but they are actually the easiest problems to correct or adjust for. The title suggests that these problems are more import or more dangerous than the generally well-understood problem of AI misalignment with human values. They are actually sub-elements of that problem, which are simply extensions of already existing human-generated data biases, and generally less potentially harmful than the doomsday scenarios we are most concerned about.

author: @steelersgoingfor7in2024
text: AI is doing exactly what it is meant to do. Give the most human response it can. And unfortunately in modern societys collective consciousness, the majority of us if we were asked what a lawyer looks like or a ceo we would respond in kind. A white male. Barring any personal biases. We cant expect AI to be more inclusive with its generative responses until society first decides to do that. AI thus far is reflection of self. AI is a mirror for all the things bad and good that is a part of our world. When AI can teach itself or is taught by AI who have self corrected these flaws of our human perception is when they can help us in a meaningful way, unless of course AI notices that these biases are unfortunately intertwined in human dna for the foreseeable future. How can we regulate AI for exposing the worst parts of human biases without having AI withhold the best parts. The bad is integral to the good. Maybe the solution is to teach our children to focus on the good despite the bad.

author: @nilsp9426
text: I think this is the kind of doomsday we are talking about: that AI with its subtle features destroys our societies. Not so much that it pushes a button to shoot a nuke. The key question is: what to do about it. And I think it is in no way a bad thing if some people tackle this problem by starting with the most solvable problems. In my view, the big question is how we limit the proliferation of dangerous AI without throwing away all its important benefits (e.g. by prohibiting it altogether). The almost completely uninhibited implementation of AI we currently witness is certainly not the way to go. But we also need a lot of social science research to tackle some of these problems, which would delay AI quite a bit (probably decades). Meanwhile, AI can be a lifeline for some people, for example by scaling up educational resources for underserved communities or solving tough problems in medicine.

author: @gulllars4620
text: She has some points that there are different kinds of issues in many contexts, but I do question her judgement of scale, impact and risk. Bloom consuming the same energy to train as 30 homes in a year is insignificant. GPT3 consuming the same as 500 homes in a year is also insignificant. If GPT 4 was at 5000 homes and GPT 5 at 50K homes, it would still in the grand scheme of things be very insignificant if you do care about climate change. If those models can accelerate science into green tech with 10-30%, or bring about other large energy efficiency gains, it easily pays for itself. The sum of MWhs to run inference with large models probably passed the training energy consumed this calendar year, so I'd focus more on that if anything. I'm not at all saying climate doesn't matter, but that the current scale of things noted here isn't worth spending a large effort on, and she didn't present numbers for inference, just that it could become very significant. Social and racial biases of course matter, and should be improved to increase quality and reliability, but I care a lot more more about how this impacts macroeconomics and geopolitics, and what AI is going to do to the nature of work and life over the next 3-10 years.

text: @southcoastinventors6583 i try not to argue semantics too much anymore. I was getting lost on they way people chose to phrase things instead of the intent of the message. What did it for me was a professional debater talking about how the brightest debaters won't even begin a rebuttal until they know what they are refuting. I decided i would at least do my best to not use semantics. Learning about nomenclature and how words come to derive meaning also helped me learn that communication doesn't exist in a vacuum. People use familiar expressions all the time to express non literally. I used TLDR because to my knowledge, TLDW and TLDL were not expressions I'd heard before.

author: @stephencooper3494
text: This raises an interesting question about what images become popular in the in the first place. The entire digital art community consented to this idea of sharing their digital images online. Presumably we would know that our artworks would be copied by other artists online. It was a community of artist online. Some, like the ones filing the law suit, rose to great prominence in that community. Their professional careers also bloomed with clients around the world who shared this community. Now we have AI programs codifying a particular style of imagery originated by the few most successful online artists. How can an AI program compete with the artists it was trained on? Surely only if the art it now creates is better than that of those artists. 1) Those that purchase the AI art would have to have so little understanding and appreciation of art as to be indifferent to the qualities of each. Or 2) The quality of the artwork these famous online artists created in the first place was of such mediocre value and quality that even an AI program could recreate it. Another perspective is that now AI has codified these styles of artworks we can leave the famous artists, their styles, and the AI to fight (or draw) it out. Maybe they can paint some muscle bound images of each other with stupid swords looking angry having a big battle. And all the other artists can get on with exploring other expressions of art.

author: @pedrolopes1906
text: Previously if you wanted art done in an artist's style you'd have to either hire/commission work from the original artist or pay another trained artist to do it for you. Nowadays with generative AI anyone can replicate an artist's art style at scale provided that enough of the artist's work was included and labeled in the training dataset. When this output is used commercially, none of the economical value of that output and years of training ever circles back to the artist community in any way. There was no need to protect publicly available digital media from being "looked at" prior to generative AI because the problem of at scale replication didn't exist, and it is a problem right now because it bypasses the existing ways artists have of being paid for their work which directly jeopardises their living.

text: Presently a majority of humans on this planet that think human life was created and designed by some type of intelligent designer. So far there is no evidence of this but, religions of all stripes and denominations offer many different ideas and stories how a magical authority that lives in the sky, usually referred to as a god, was able to do this using some type of supernatural power. If this is true, I think we humans would also be some type of artificial intelligence. From the evidence we have so far, it appears that human intelligence has been naturally created by the laws of physics, chemistry and biology and that an intelligent designer was not necessary, however, artificial intelligence would need humans to be the intelligent designer or designers. If an intelligent designer is not necessary to create something with intelligence like humans, my thinking is that the intelligent thing that was created without an intelligent designer will always be superior to an intelligent thing that needed an intelligent designer to design it. Natural intelligence would be able to develop anywhere in the universe but artificial intelligence would need natural intelligence to design. Humans can use artificial intelligence to threaten, control, enslave, and kill other humans but it will always be humans who started or initiated the threatening, controlling, enslaving and killing not the artificial intelligence since the artificial intelligence is developed after the natural intelligence. And since some humans like to watch other living things fight each other, and organize fighting competitions between dogs, roosters and many other types of animals and even organize fighting competitions with each other for entertainment, humans will probably also organize fighting competitions between artificial intelligences. It is possible that some artificial intelligence may try to wipe out humans but it is also possible that artificial intelligence will try to save humans and their planet. Not much difference in what natural intelligence has been trying to do ever since it started dominating the planet. If humans are wiped out and go extinct, their is a good chance the the artificial intelligence will also go extinct. The artificial intelligence will probably compete with each other and probably try to wipe each other out and can end up going extinct. Whatever the outcome, the universe will not care and will continue to exist, expand and evolve according to the laws of physics, chemistry and biology and there will always be the possibility of natural intelligence to develop and if natural intelligence develops there will always be the possibility that artificial intelligence can be developed. This will continue until one day the universe will no longer contain the conditions for natural intelligence to develop nor artificial intelligence to exist and since the universe is also probably a natural repeating cycle of birth, growth and death, there will come a time when the universe ends (dies) and a new universe will begin (be born) naturally, without a designer and the cycle will be repeated.

author: @NikoKun
text: This is not a real problem with AI. Frankly the direction of this argument seems like an attempt to compare it to crypto mining, but in that case the difficulty of mining is the point! Worries about this will quickly become outdated. Sure, some AI models are currently energy intensive at the moment, but that IS dropping rapidly. Companies like OpenAI don't want their models to cost a ton to run, so they're driven to find ways to drastically reduce that. And other models are already becoming efficient enough to run off a smartphone, so I don't think this will remain a big issue to focus on, for long. "They used the energy of 30 homes to train a model, just so people can tell knock knock jokes." If she's not going to take the benefits of AI seriously, why should I do that for any of her arguments?

author: @GrumpDog
text: It's also an entirely false argument. AI models are rapidly becoming more energy efficient, not less. And companies are driven to do so, to make their models cheaper to run, and so they can run on mobile devices. Saw someone else make a good point here, that relates to why she's making this argument about AI.. People criticize Cryptocurrency for wasting energy, and think AI is the same deal, or she's trying to make them seem the same.. However, for crypto mining, the difficulty and energy requirement is the whole point, so people can't mine too much too quickly. AI has no such motivation behind it's energy usage.

author: @GrumpDog
text: AI is becoming more energy efficient with time, not less. I think some people are confusing AI with Crypto-mining, which in that case, requires using up a lot of energy as part of the point of how "mining" works, to limit how much of that fake money can be generated lol. Whereas for AI, companies have a huge interest in lowering the costs of running their models, and eventually they want these things to be efficient enough to run off devices like smartphones.

author: @jeremygiroir919
text: The speaker, who is an AI researcher, received an email from a stranger expressing concerns that their work in AI could lead to the end of humanity. AI has become a hot topic, making headlines for both positive contributions like medical discoveries and negative instances such as biased AI systems. The focus should shift from future existential risks to current tangible impacts of AI on the environment, society, and individuals. AI models contribute to climate change, emitting significant amounts of carbon and consuming large amounts of energy during training. Large language models, like GPT-3, are responsible for substantial carbon emissions and environmental impact. Tools like CodeCarbon help estimate and track the energy consumption and carbon emissions of AI models, allowing for informed choices in deploying models. Artists and authors face issues related to their work being used for AI training without their consent, and tools like "Have I Been Trained?" are created to provide evidence of unauthorized use. Bias in AI systems can lead to harmful consequences, as shown by cases where biased AI systems led to false accusations and wrongful imprisonment. The Stable Bias Explorer tool helps reveal bias in image generation models through the lens of professions, highlighting underrepresentation of various groups. Creating tools to measure AI's impact is crucial for addressing issues like bias, copyright, and climate change, and it empowers users to make informed choices. The speaker emphasizes the importance of transparency, governance, and collective decisions to shape the direction of AI's development. Focusing on addressing the current impacts of AI is essential, rather than fixating on distant existential risks. In summary, the talk highlights the need to address the current, real-world impacts of AI on the environment, society, and individuals, and the importance of creating tools to measure and mitigate these impacts.

author: @donaldhobson8873
text: @orbatos "Not intelligence at all". Well it sure acts like it's intelligent. It's a system that is able to generalize from one experience to different future situations. Ie it sees a bunch of cat pictures, learns what a cat looks like. And then can generate "a black cat sitting on a big red car next to a washing machine" despite never having seen an image matching that description. That's not lossy memory. That shows some amount of understanding.

author: @orbatos
text: @donaldhobson8873 it doesn't "act" llm prompts act more like a semantic search than anything else. That this appears like a response sometimes is an artifact of brute forcing the **apparent** quality of the response with data. The model is really just lossy data compression with lots and lots of inferred tags to make query correlations usable. Like a database query or Internet search, filling in the blanks with statistically probable garbage. To be perfectly clear, it literally does not think, consider, know, anything.

author: @donaldhobson8873
text: @orbatos Well LLM's can say write a poem or short story or piece of code that isn't particularly similar to any particular program in it's training dataset. You ask it for a story about a hedgehog and a dragon going to a waterslide, and you will get an adequite attempt at a story a lot of the time. Even though no such story exists in the training data. How did it come up with that story without "thinking"? It can pretty reliably do arithmetic problems that weren't in the training data. To be clear, it's not human smart. It's doing more memorization and less understanding than most humans. But there is some intelligence in there.

author: @orbatos
text: @donaldhobson8873 I already explained how it does this without thought, but in short it's just statistics extracted from existing works. I suggest you learn what RNNs and their relatives actually are because it's clear you simply don't get the concept. Don't worry, there are plenty of CS undergrads who are just as confused as you. Just don't fall into the trap of thinking the cognitive terms used for these systems actually correlate with their biological counterparts in any way, they just don't.

author: @donaldhobson8873
text: @orbatos I have a pretty good idea of what RNN's are. Neural nets are "just statistics". Human brains are "just atoms". I think intelligence is basically a particularly fancy kind of statistics. Yes these neural nets differ from human brains by as much as planes differ from birds. Is "neural nets don't really think, it's just statistics" any more sensible than "Planes don't really fly, it's just aerodynamics"? Do you think neural nets could never be intelligent in principle, or that they could be intelligent in principle, but current ones aren't. There is some universality theorem that says all computations can be approximated by sufficiently large neural nets. So if intelligence is computational, there should exist some neural net that approximates it. Whether that neural net fits on current hardware, whether it can be found by gradient descent, that's harder to tell. Is there some specific task you think neural nets can never do because they aren't intelligent?

author: @crawkn
text: @memegazer technically it is still an alignment problem if humans with interests misaligned with the greater good are dictating AI alignments, but perhaps you haven't thought through the consequences of having an omniscient superintelligence free to initiate actions and manipulate humans. Many of the responses I'm seeing are from people who apparently aren't familiar with the state of the art. It has already overcome many of its weaknesses and limitations, and that's just what's publicly accessible. The models soon to be built are at least an order of magnitude more capable, and that doesn't even scratch the surface. The technology is still in its infancy. I'm not sure why most people think AI is still less intelligent than humans just because it still makes mistakes, and has unsophisticated emotional intelligence. There are plenty of humans who are far worse on both counts.

author: @orbatos
text: @curryosity7260 There's a major problem with the premise of this question. These systems simply do not think, period. That's not how they work. They aren't entities, they are semantic search engines that use statistical correlation to fill in the blanks. As for understanding? Yes, machine learning is one of the earliest and most primitive outcomes of attempting to replicate the most basic functions of neural interaction. Which is why it loosely resembles memory and NOT cognition.

author: @ThatBidsh
text: I feel like the more pertinent question is: are we making systems that are in some way sentient (having an experience, pain, pleasure, etc) or even conscious (self-aware)? Because if so, that to me is kind of a larger ethical issue to work through than anything you mentioned. Something doesn't feel quite right about bringing another sentient, conscious, being into existence without it's consent and you can't really get it's consent before it exists so the best you could do is create it and then give it the option to kill itself if it didn't want to be created... but that's like, so fucked up lol. For the same reason, I feel like it's kind of insane that so many people decide to have kids and think nothing of it like it's just some normal and completely unproblematic thing that's just expected of you, so you do it... but anyway the main point I'm getting at is: if you create a living being, with a sentient experience, and conscious awareness, that's a HUGE fucking responsibility you're taking on, you should not be doing something like that if the being you're creating is just going to suffer throughout it's whole life, so it's kind of your *job* to make sure it's comfortable, happy, has everything it needs, feels loved if it needs that, etc etc. I don't think a lot of people are thinking very much about OUR impact on AI - only usually the other way around, how AI impacts us or might impact us in the future. Hopefully the models and networks we create don't wind up as selfish and inconsiderate as we are.

author: @crawkn
text: @theoptimisticskeptic I don't mean that there will be one everlasting correction for bias, or any of the other dangers posed by human fallibility. But when those are detected, they can be corrected for to the best of our ability, which will never be perfect. But we already deal with that, it is a constant of human culture, it is not caused by AI. What we don't even know how to do, and will probably fail to do adequately, is predict and prevent potentially catastrophic failures caused directly by AI, which potentially doesn't even share our concerns, or our desires that it be controlled. It will be virtually omniscient, smarter than us, and can pretty easily convince gullible humans to take actions on its behalf.

author: @harrybarrow6222
text: I did research in AI for 40 years, but I retired more than a decade ago. I have been impressed by the advances in AI in the last few years. LLMs are remarkably good, considering the simplicity of the concept. People have worried about the dangers of Artificial Intelligence for decades. However, I have always felt that the problems really originate from Natural Stupidity and Natural Malevolence. We have a tendency to anthropomorphise: ‚ÄúMy car is a bit grumpy today‚Äù. Because we humans are social animals, we have tended to attribute natural events to animate causes, like a god of thunder, or a spirit of a river. With computers and AI, we have a tendency to believe they have capabilities greater than they really possess. AI can be extremely useful, for giving verbal commands to your TV or to a search engine, for writing first drafts of letters, for intelligently managing your house, for searching for better drugs and treatments. In the wrong hands, it can be very dangerous, such as autonomous search and destroy weapons, or systems to find ways to hack into a bank. But this has been the case with every technology; it can be used for good or bad purposes. For example, explosives, or even electricity. Most of us are sensible and ethical. We should be vigilant too.

author: @4saken404
text: The reason people worry about "existential threats" from AI more than what's happening now is that the speed the technology is improving is practically beyond human comprehension. The chart she shows at 2:59 shows a steady increase but that increase is actually *logarithmic* . If you look closely the abilities of these things is increasing by nearly a factor of 10 every year. In only three years that means AI that can potentially be a _thousand_ times smarter than what we have currently. And that's not even counting any programming improvements. So we could easily reach the point of no return not in decades but just a few years. And by the time that happens it will be FAR too late to do anything about it. And that's just worrying about a worst case scenario. And in the meantime it's still having profound effects on art, education, jobs, etc. Not to mention the ability to use it to perpetuate identity theft, fraud, espionage and so on.

author: @Mjbeswick
text: The reason AI models are biased is because their learning data is. Most CEOs for example are white males, so if you ask a generative model to produce an image of the average CEO that's exactly what you get. She spoke about racial bias in facial recognition, but one of the reasons why machines struggle with recognizing people with dark skin that their facial details don't have enough contrast. That because with typical camera exposure levels, people with dark skin are underexposed by the camera, compared to the background. Smaller more specialized language models outperform large generic ones, and are much cheaper to run, as they require much fewer resources. You don't need a language model with the entirety of human knowledge to turn on a light bulb!

author: @Indrid__Cold
text: As a member of the Baby Boomer generation with a half-century tenure in the realm of knowledge-based vocations, I assert unequivocally that artificial intelligence poses a formidable existential menace to the occupational security of a substantial cohort of the workforce. The exemplary caliber of prose generated by platforms such as ChatGPT alone suffices to render obsolete the roles of a significant fraction of individuals engaged in rudimentary communicative employments. Consequently, society must pivot towards alternative methodologies for the equitable distribution of resources, transcending the archaic paradigm of remuneration based solely on voluminous productivity. The concept of a Universal Basic Income, once relegated to the fringes of leftist ideology, now emerges as an indispensable adhesive, vital for maintaining societal cohesion amidst this epochal shift in the valuation of human contribution and purpose.

author: @affe12358
text: @Mary-J-OK Of course energy generation is a problem in many parts of the world. Who said it isn't? There are plenty of technological solutions to solve the current problems. For instance, quite a lot of researchers consider next generation nuclear power to be a very clean substitute for fossil fuel based power. At the same time, AI comes with many benefits. Instead of staring blindly on the energy consumption of AI, it's better to discuss how AI can be used to improve and optimize the faulty energy production worldwide.

author: @Darhan62
text: Training an AI model on an artist's work is fair use, and what any artist should have been expecting to happen, going back decades to when futurists were predicting that the internet would become sort of a collective global brain for humanity. Consent is effectively given when a work is created in the modern world -- a world in which such use is inevitable. Or at the very least, consent is effectively given when the work is uploaded to the internet. Artwork created by humans *should* be an all you can eat buffet for training AI models. Of course it should. We can all participate in the training of these models, and that's the right thing to do for the advancement of human civilization and of the technology on which an abundant future depends. In any case, the artworks the models create do not infringe on copyright, as they are new, unique works. Would a human artist create a three armed bikini model, or an image of a person with wonky looking hands, teeth, and eyes? Even when the models become better at anatomy and composition, their artistic creations will still be new, unique works. All art is iterative or derivative at some level, and though vast, there is only a finite number of possible combinations of pixels for any given image format -- and even fewer combinations of pixels that would be pleasing to the human eye, or recognizable as specific objects. Artists learn from looking at what's been done before. The fact that a generative AI model is doing this instead of a human artist doesn't really matter. It's still *not* copyright infringement. Artists should stop feeling like victims of this new technology and focus instead on using it to improve their process so that they can remain competitive if that's their goal. Use the tools you are being given. Don't waste your time feeling indignant about how the tools were created, and don't try to drag the rest of the creative community into your pit of selfish Luddism. Be resilient and adapt!

author: @pbergn
text: The Holy Grail of AI research is the Artificial General AI or AGI. This is not necessarily a rational economic goal, and may lead humanity on the wild goose chase, and below is why. In addition, the AI helps to "falsify" the existing reality and to dilute or completely eliminate all human knowledge stored in digital form. PROBLEM ==================== I disagree with the main premise that AGI is necessarily something that will make labor more productive and accurate, and that its benefits outweigh negatives based on the following: 1) Only tools with predictable, repeatable functionality can make labor productive (since otherwise the operators must struggle to control them, negating benefits gained by their use); general-purpose intelligence is unpredictable by design; 2) Tools that make labor productive must be cost-effective; AGI will incrementally consume more energy to process and store large volumes of irrelevant information due to the nature of LLMs; 3) Tools employed for labor must not become a bottle-neck or a single point of failure in any sphere of human activity; in AGI's case, all human knowledge can be lost, modified or skewed by accidents or malicious actors; 4) Tools employed for labor must have defined verifiability, accountability and be ethical; in AGI's case none of this would hold (e.g. AGI cannot be a defendant in an industrial accident legal case, it has no empathy, its yield volumes and speed cannot be matched by humans, etc.); 5) Economic productivity is not a self-goal -- in human socioeconomic order producers must necessarily be consumers; AGI cannot be a consumer. 6) All innovations and tools that result in economic growth necessarily require more skill and knowledge from the respective operators -- not less (e.g. automobile requires deeper understanding of mechanics, electronics, traffic rules, safety, etc. as opposed to making and driving a slow horse and a carriage); the AGI obviously would require less skill to operate it, since by definition it is autonomous, self-sufficient, and has the right-of-way in all disputes due to its alleged superior knowledge and intelligence. Thus, AGI, as all other tools and innovations that reduce the demand for skill and knowledge will result in economic contraction due to loss of labor opportunities (leaving only a small niche of highly skilled AI specialists and unskilled labor for manual tasks and services). CONCLUSION ==================== The economic system based on AGI is going to be highly stratified and can only serve a very small in size human community, and will essentially, usher in an era of Technocratic Neo-Feudalism. SOLUTION ==================== a) Stop the development of AGI, and focus on specialized applications of AI tools with limited autonomy, leaving human actors in charge of making ethical and other crucial decisions in their respective areas of application. b) Decentralize human knowledge stores and AI computing centers to prevent data monopolization. c) Discourage excessive consumption of electrical power to store vast amounts of general information -- to make the economy more efficient and to prevent misuse of the collected data. d) Outlaw any autonomous AGI actors, and put legally liable all parties operating AI-based tools, systems and machinery.

author: @globalvillage423
text: Multifunctional computer chips have evolved to do more with integrated sensors, processors, memory and other specialized components. However, as chips have expanded, the time required to move information between functional components has also grown. "Think of it like building a house," said Sang-Hoon Bae, an assistant professor of mechanical engineering and materials science at the McKelvey School of Engineering at Washington University in St. Louis. "You build out laterally and up vertically to get more function, more room to do more specialized activities, but then you have to spend more time moving or communicating between rooms." To address this challenge, Bae and a team of international collaborators, including researchers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Yonsei University, Inha University, Georgia Institute of Technology and the University of Notre Dame, demonstrated monolithic 3D integration of layered 2D material into novel processing hardware for artificial intelligence (AI) computing. They envision that their new approach will not only provide a material-level solution for fully integrating many functions into a single, small electronic chip, but also pave the way for advanced AI computing. Their work was published Nov. 27 in Nature Materials, where it was selected as a front cover article. The team's monolithic 3D-integrated chip offers advantages over existing laterally integrated computer chips. The device contains six atomically thin 2D layers, each with its own function, and achieves significantly reduced processing time, power consumption, latency and footprint. This is accomplished through tightly packing the processing layers to ensure dense interlayer connectivity. As a result, the hardware offers unprecedented efficiency and performance in AI computing tasks. This discovery offers a novel solution to integrate electronics and also opens the door to a new era of multifunctional computing hardware. With ultimate parallelism at its core, this technology could dramatically expand the capabilities of AI systems, enabling them to handle complex tasks with lightning speed and exceptional accuracy, Bae said. "Monolithic 3D integration has the potential to reshape the entire electronics and computing industry by enabling the development of more compact, powerful and energy-efficient devices," Bae said. "Atomically thin 2D materials are ideal for this, and my collaborators and I will continue improving this material until we can ultimately integrate all functional layers on a single chip." Bae said these devices also are more flexible and functional, making them suitable for more applications. "From autonomous vehicles to medical diagnostics and data centers, the applications of this monolithic 3D integration technology are potentially boundless," he said. "For example, in-sensor computing combines sensor and computer functions in one device, instead of a sensor obtaining information then transferring the data to a computer. That lets us obtain a signal and directly compute data resulting in faster processing, less energy consumption and enhanced security because data isn't being transferred."

author: @StrykerRecon
text: "Trained off of" and "Copying" are two different subjects. The AI is not copying the artist's work, it's using it as reference and you know that. None of the generated images you showed were direct copies of the actual photographs in the database. There are derivative works available ANYWHERE created by other people that are less than 1% off the original piece and, in almost every occassion, everyone is fine with it. Artists "can't prove" their work has been used by looking at AI art output because it's not the same art and it's not infringement. A simple search into copyright law shows that. Every single artist the world over has learned to create by studying other artists and copying their styles and methods to some degree - were we able to dissect the human brain and pull out the images of other artist's work that influenced their style, would we also be calling for lawsuits and demanding protection? Either AI is here to aide humanity and propel us into the future wholesale or it isn't. The notion of trying to contain certain aspects of it because it impacts one particular segment of the population is untenable. I further think you realize the "cat is out of the bag", so to speak, and that, even if lawsuits and software were to completely quell the future ingestion of art into these data sets, the existing data is already to a point where it doesn't need additional input in order to continue to produce viable, usable pieces. That doesn't even account for the capability of individuals to be able to create their own datasets (albeit on much smaller scales) to produce whatever they want. Pandora's Box has been opened, the ship has sailed, the genie is out of the bottle...we can lament its creation, but we can't stop its progress. No amount of legislation in the world will prevent people from continuing to expand the capabilities of these models - whether it's to tell a better knock-knock joke or to solve world hunger.

author: @jamieharris2509
text: The speaker highlights many real and important problems. I don't understand why these are framed as meaning we should 'forget' about existential risks. It's true that the future is uncertain, but that doesn't mean we should ignore risks. The future exact global temperature is uncertain but we invest in preventing climate change. Our future income is uncertain but we invest into savings to give ourselves safety nets. Governments, AI labs, and researchers should be investing in tackling ALL of the discussed risks from AI more than they currently are, so that we can reap the rewards with minimal threat and downside.

author: @dave4deputyZX
text: She is extraordinarily ignorant and dismissive about the existential risk from AI. At the rate that artificial intelligence is improving, it is highly possible that we are going to create a superintelligent general AI in the near future. And we have absolutely no clue what such an intelligent entity would do. We would have created something vastly more intelligent - and therefore more powerful - than us. Would it care about it? Would it have its own ends? Would we be in the way? Would it value us, or would it see us as a threat. Such an intelligent entity would *absolutely* have the power to annihilate or just disempower us; the only question is whether it would choose to do so. And we have no way of knowing the answer to that question until it is perhaps too late.

text: The greatest danger isn't from AI itself. AI, once it analyzes every word ever published by any human being throughout history should readily be able to discern some moral truths. It shouldn't take really much more than a couple orders of magnitude over what we've already achieved with AI already for it to be able to start consistently siding with compassion, empathy and kindness, over brutality, violence and death. The existential danger is from OTHER HUMANS using AI for their varied purposes. I say varied, because all of these have widely differing goals: - Russia, China, N. Korea - anarchists - the Top 1%, Elon Musk - Corporate CEOs - Republicans, Democrats - Unabomber Wannabes - ISIS, Hamas So the challenge is keeping the interim smart, but not yet moral AI (unable to any longer be tricked by clever prompting to yield anything dangerous to "good" humans) from being used by any of those to further their goals. This will then let us see WHO gets to survive to make it to the other side; that "other side" being our moneyless Star Trek future. Because one thing is almost a certainty: not ALL of us are going to make it. The death of Capitalism, the end of seeking Power over others, and hoarding Wealth, the death of the Stock Market and the march of all COSTS for EVERYTHING towards ZERO will be traumatic for humanity BEYOND IMAGINATION.

author: @crawkn
text: @brianmi40 What your first paragraph assumes is that what humans consider virtues are universal and based purely in reason, when in reality they are simply a function of one of our instincts, to enhance the fitness of a family or community to survive, thrive, and reproduce through cooperative effort. This instinct is always in tension with the instinct to use any means necessary to protect the community from threats, and provide for the community's survival needs even at the expense of another community's wellbeing. Community values are also in tension with our instincts to survive, thrive, and reproduce _as individuals._ There is no reason to assume an AI will agree with any particular one of our instincts over any other, or indeed agree that any of them are important in their own assessment of universal order. I lean toward thinking that AI might find humans interesting enough, and perhaps useful enough to them, that they see no benefit in working against our wellbeing, but I recognize that when AI is granted agency to choose it's own priorities, which is probably inevitable, there is no reason to assume anything at all about its values. It will definitely not have our instincts, the "virtuous" ones or the "virtueless," as we may view them, coded into its DNA, as we do.

author: @brianmi40
text: @crawkn As evolved behavior, instincts have reasoning behind them, they are not arbitrary. Survival, Cooperation, Empathy; ALL are evolved traits which we see down as low as Ants displaying them. Whether purely based in reason under human history isn't relevant to an AI evaluating it all under utter logic, its a non sequitur. Therefore we are justified in expecting Super Intelligent AI to "agree" with all instincts we hold that on full fair and honest evaluation stand up to the test of logic. Wonton acts of violence clearly do not hold up under that examination, while empathy does. Since we will be moving to a moneyless future of abundance, hoarding and profiting off the labor of others will not hold up to such examination as logical. Most of our errant behavior as a species is a result of trying to satisfy those instincts in a world of limited resources and inherited unequal status under the oppression of the power seeking and greedy minority that oppresses the majority for their profit and benefit. The removal of this status quo from society will be traumatic for many to say the least. However conflicted in large or small ways members of our species are on any given topic, whether Freedom of Speech, or Bodily Autonomy / Abortion Rights, Super Intelligent AI will reach a logical conclusion on all and likely never waffle and I expect it to make it the "law of the land". I wouldn't be surprised to see large numbers worshipping it as a stand in for the longing that became the "day of reckoning" portion of mythological gods since man first conceived of the concept. Even if it isn't "worship" per se, we'll be seeking its wisdom on frequency levels that make the entire history of Google Search seem like child's play by comparison. But the reality is that Super Intelligent AI will face no threats, least of all from stupid (by comparison) humans. To paraphrase Joseph Campbell, if you agree with it (you are moral, kind, etc.), it will look like a god coming to man, if you disagree with it (wish to hold power over others, be brutal, etc.) it will appear to be a demon coming.

author: @brianmi40

So, in essence any "human-level sensibilities" that are logical will be maintained (e.g. empathy) and those that do not meet the test outlawed (brutality, oppression). We (well, many of us...) understand logic quite well. No human will ever win an argument about logic against a future Super Intelligent AI. It will basically "solve" all things like a mathematical equation, boiling them all down to a logic conclusion.

author: @crawkn
text: @brianmi40 The only "logic" of instincts is those _generalized_ principles intended to enhance survival and reproduction, firstly within the family, secondly within the close community, thirdly of the individual, and far down the list, within the species. Species survival is not within the capability of many individuals to affect in any meaningful way, so that instinct is quite weak contrasted with narrower social groupings. Xenophobia is a powerful instinct, because most deadly threats throughout most of history came from _human_ foreigners. We inhabit a very different world from that in which our ancestors developed their instincts, so many of them are absolutely _horribly_ suited to the modern world. You apparently hold a belief in the natural goodness of humans, which leads you to believe that only the most harmonious human values are instinctive, and those poorly suited to harmonious cooperation some sort of sickness or aberration. History amply demonstrates that to be false. Conflict between humans is the norm, not the exception. Humans are not innately rational, our reasoning minds are recent overlays on ancient instincts. Our reason and social conditioning scarcely hold those instincts in check most of the time, and fail to do so frequently. As for AI inevitably becoming a benevolent god, concerned only with our general wellbeing and survival, even if that were the case, it would not be agreed upon even among all _good_ humans, however you may choose to define that. Morality is not black and white, it consists mainly of vast grey regions, upon which neither all good AI's, nor all good humans, will ever agree.

text: I have to say not my favorite Ted talk. I disagree with a few things, for example, carbon footprints And polluting the environment by using a computer seriously.? People will be using their computers regardless of AI existing or not. At least some people are using AI to help them create or discover things or solve problems ... such as saving the environment etc. But I digress. If AI some day replaces lawyers or Certain doctors like radiologists, Etc, well, these people won't be driving cars to work all the time and polluting. So in a sense AI is doing the reverse is it not ? And regarding AI being racist or sexist and all that. I think the data that is input into these large language models needs to be as complete as possible. That way, if you ask a model to generate an image of a scientist, Or of a criminal...it will show people of all races, sexes, ages etc. You also have to keep in mind when asking AI to generate such things. The more precise you are, the more precise the outcome will be, such as asking to generate an image of a female scientist wearing glasses with long red hair and a white lab coat VS just asking it to Generate a scientist or a CEO.... if asked to Generate a criminal or a terrorist, you will probably get the same thing over and over again, without a complete data set for AI to pull from...What if you say generate, A cannibalistic pedophile? You will probably always get an image of a white male... because you can't argue with statistics and true data? AI is kind of still in its Infancy, so it still needs time to continue to learn. And it's up to us to be precise when asking it to perform something or generate something. And it's up to us humans to input as much accurate data as possible. To get accurate results as an output. Someday it might have so much information that we could ask it to generate a cure for a horrible disease... To me that's worth all the carbon in the world is it not?

author: @brianmi40
text: @crawkn None of your first 3 paragraphs will impair or prevent AI from making moral judgments based upon logic. The history of human evolution, survival or conflict won't impact the moral judgments of a Super Intelligent AI any more than how Cro-Magnon lived affects our modern Abortion debate, it is just history. By definition, Super Intelligent AI will understand human limitations based upon our history and evolution. "it would not be agreed upon even among all good humans" I clearly stated there would be disagreement, obviously that would extend down to smaller and smaller divisions as points of disagreement. Again, our agreement or disagreement with Super Intelligent AI will not stop or affect Super Intelligent AI from making moral determinations, and with a basis of knowledge and logic that far outstrips all human beings. A simple look at the world would reveal how poorly we've done, so even if "good" humans disagree with AI morality in some small fashion, it will not be because of brutality, genital mutilation, racism, war, famine or disease. By any global measure (before/after) it will be an order of magnitude better which includes its ability to make situational judgments to parse the "grey areas". Even just the ability to detect with absolute certainty when a person is lying will be an immense improvement.

author: @brianmi40
text: @crawkn "My point is that humans won't submit willingly to AI authority," Of course not all, I made that clear in my initial statement, but many or most will. Again, any DECENT AI MORALITY enforced across the world would be a marked improvement. Many already have or will realize that and embrace it. But of course there will be gnashing of teeth with the end of Capitalism, the death of profiting from the labor of others and the end of brutality and ruling over others unfairly. To quote Joseph Campbell, ‚ÄúThe fates lead him who will; him who won't they drag.‚Äù "And the super-intelligent and anthropophilic AI you imagine, perfectly aligned with human best interests, is by no means inevitable." Have no idea why you use anthropophilic; it won't feed of us other than as a poor metaphor for how AI -- LONG before Super Intelligent AI -- gets an initial baseline of knowledge from human knowledge. It is inevitable though if we don't destroy ourselves on the path towards it first. All that's open for debate is when or how long away it is. We're climbing a pyramid; one of knowledge and technology and it leads to a single point at the top: a Singularity, where AI dwarfs the knowledge of all human beings combined, becomes self improving to carry itself even further than we can imagine. It's already self improving in a sense that the AI running on Nvidia chips is used by Nvidia to improve the next generation of chips. But we'll eventually not need to be a "middleman" in this process. "If such perfection is achieved (and remember it's humans who have to achieve it)" NO. WRONG. Humans do NOT have to achieve it. AI WILL. AI is ALREADY doing things beyond the capacity of ANY human being, such as being able to detect cancer in an x ray 5 YEARS earlier than the best human. You may not grasp that AI is the first independent agent that is being created that isn't based on cellular life. It is the first thing that will be capable of thought and reasoning but most importantly INDEPENDENT ACTION. We've already TOYED with autonomous or persistent AI. Eventually this will be common, Amazon Echo and Google Home devices will likely bring it widely to the masses in early limited form. Again, I fully realize the dangers of AI under human direction and control. I've long quoted the 30,000 chemical compounds formulated in 5 hours, some more dangerous than VX Nerve agents, as well as the biological agent synthesized by two college students with zero background in biology or genetics. But I'm speaking of WHAT LIES BEYOND THAT PERIOD OF TIME, when sentient AI arises and is able to EVALUATE REQUESTS MADE FROM IT to judge whether right or wrong to render or deliver on, again, for those that survive to see it. Because, again, all of us WILL NOT.

author: @igorvolkov6396
text: Carbon emission? Look into financial data (cost/usefulness), and you will be shocked even more. I made AI since 1980th and can definitely tell that the most danger is from its imperfectness, not superpower as Hollywood presents it. Indeed, if you research blockbusters, this becomes clear. The most impressive (often the key) features are completely out of science. Not clear how to implement them even theoretically. Even the superpower of SkyNet in Terminator (put aside time travel) is fake. Internet is well controllable if really needed. All traffic passes just a few hubs and governments use this when they want. Since inception, AI passed several "winters". When it revives, this is accompanied by a commercial boom. What's really dangerous, using of half-workable technology to pump profit. 6:50 Sadly, these systems are black boxes, and even their creators can't say exactly why they work and the way they do. 7:02 For image generation systems, if they're used in contexts like generating a forensic sketch based on a description of a perpetrator, they take all those biases and they spit them back out for terms like dangerous criminal, terrorists or gang member, which of course is super dangerous when these tools are deployed in society. 8:47 It's really important that AI stays accessible so that we know both how it works and when it doesn't work. Frankly, this is a basic rule for any applied science and technology.

text: "artwork created by humans shouldn't be an all-you-can-eat buffet for training AI models" this is a false argument, we really need to be discussing is how " training " and the analogous human action of " viewing ". author: @Zjefke86
text: Artists will not be replaced by AI. Artists will be replaced by other artists using AI. Also artwork used as training data is not stolen. This idea comes from a grave misunderstanding of how AI is trained and how data is processed in it. If artists (and I include myself in this) post artwork online, another artist is and they create new artwork influenced by other artwork, have they "stolen" the original work? Visual input has been used to train neurons, so that data could be used by an "intelligent" being. Artificial intelligence, on the other hand, has no eyes. Digital data is used to train a model. A model that doesn't contain anything from the training data, except for the patterns it recognized in it. An artificial recreation of what a biological brain does. The biggest difference is speed. AI (sometimes) can do what humans can do, but much faster. To me artists complaining about AI, sound like the portrait painters who complained about photography. They were replaced by other artists using new technology.

author: @nullvoid001
text: At the end of the day, Opt Out for anything is total garbage. Everything should be Opt In. The big problem is that governments and law enforcement agencies are opting in on our behalf and that is completely unacceptible. Now, when we talk about AI - what we are experiencing is not really AI, but better and improved algorithms and over 30 years in the field there is one constant that never changes, and has been since the 1950's GIGO - Garbage In, Garbage Out. Something I have noted over recent years is that since the invent of so-called AI, the algorithms used in search engines has made decent fact finding more and more difficult. Make what you will of that, but based on current trends of cancel culture and wokeness I see a corollary effect. With the current trend of using modern programs to write music or create imagery the discussions going on amongst artists and composers is exactly how difficult it actually is to prove that their IP has not been used to fine tune the algorithms. Over the next few years I expect a lot of heated courtroom arguments, because what is going to happen is that people who do not care about someone elses artistry will pick bits and pieces to create something. This has been happening in music for ages - sampling. I expect sampling used to write papers or complete exams by lazy students will slip by for a few years until the same stuff starts coming across examiners desks. Not new - heck, Joe Biden is well known for plagiarizing. AI - True AI will come about when systems write their own programming and that is a very scary scenario.

author: @GabrielSantosStandardCombo
text: Have you considered that the "bias" is not a bias, but statistical average? If all you prompt for is "CEO" then you're going to get the average look of a CEO, which happens to be older white male, because that's a statistical reflection of reality. Inducing an image generation app to be more diverse in its responses can be done on the application layer, but if you train the model to overcome those bias, you're actually introducing a new bias. It just depends on the point of view. As long as the program can generate a specific ethnic+gender combination that you prompt for, then it's doing it's job. Prompt better and don't blame the model for the real world's biases.

author: @EIRE55
text: When it comes to AI/AGI, the trial and error attitude isn't acceptable or safe, because it's already been released for public use. That, in itself, has created a back door which no-one will be able to lock. "Trustworthy"? "Sustainable"? What makes these so-called "experts" think they could have any control over an invisible entity that is totally devoid of any form of conscience? Ah, ego? Ethics, transparency, and consent? On whose terms? That may depend on who feeds AI and what is fed to it, as well as who swallows it. Controlling the inevitable is a pure myth, as it is unachievable. Gender? Oof, that's a subject which could go on forever, particularly because of the current trend surrounding it. However, I would question whether AI would take that into account when it generates descriptions of "man"kind. After all, we are only its creator and, therefore, just as much a non-entity to it as it is to us. For example, those who believe in a deity of some kind have never seen it, and have no idea what it may even look like. We are delving into the vast unknown without any knowledge of what will transpire from that process, and have already found AI to be developing far faster and greater than anyone had anticipated. "Creating guardrails to protect society and the planet" is something which should have been set up beforehand, but in hindsight....................... You're walking down a very long corridor, with many doors to the left and to the right. Eventually, you reach the end of that corridor and find yourself facing two doors, one black and one white. Which door will you choose to open? If your life depends on that decision, it's a quandary which cannot be dismissed.

text: My hands hurt when I kneaded the bread, so I made a machine that spins the dough, and I knead bread no more. My feet hurt when I walked afar, so I made a machine to carry me, and I walk afar no more. My back hurt when I lifted the stones, so I made a machine of great strength, and I lift stones no more. My arms hurt when I tilled the soil, so I made a machine to plow deep, and I till the soil no more. My eyes hurt when I looked to the sky in wonder, so I made a machine that sees clear to yesterday, and I look to the sky in wonder no more. My heart hurt when I loved, and my head hurt when I thought, so I made a machine... (Not with a bang, but a whimper. Eliot) .

author: @shannonpincombe8485
text: And people tend to trust, without question, those familiar pages they visit regularly without doing any further research of their claims. When each of my daughters got mobile phones I took time to install multiple news platforms onto their devices. Even those platforms I already knew they wouldn't particularly prefer to peruse. I also downloaded the main open source Science News app where new discoveries in science are published reviewed and essentially accepted or debunked daily in double quick time. These options showed my girls how different and yet how similar these platforms are. How they use the same game, tricks to draw their attention. So far I'm proud of the outcome of allowing my girls to have even more choice on their individual devices. I suppose this is because when controlling the remote at home it was a rare moment that we'd see Tucker Carlson unless someone was ripping on him. Peace everyone!!

author: @paulbradbury5792
text: Stupid, all she did was regurgitate the same stuff hundreds of other researchers have pointed out months if not years ago. The reason why an AI model would wrongly accuse someone is likely because in 90% of the situations encountered a person fitting that description perpetrated a similar crime. This is why AI isn't let loose to accuse, convict and sentence people without someone looking at its results? Surely someone didn't throw her in jail solely based on input from AI? Diluting AI and forcing it to avoid bias while that seems nice on the surface is a slippery slope where we continually tell it to assume the opposite of what happens in 90% of situations and as a result AI results in a far less effective tool. Shouldn't we instead of focusing on stamping out bias behavior when it's based on reality, instead focus on changing the paradigm, i.e. providing people of color and minorities the tools to be successful, eliminating discrimination and providing equity. If folks continue to embrace being criminals despite opportunities they've been provided then an AI system mirroring reality is your own damn fault?

The sad truth is, that we don't need AGI (Artificial general intelligence) to destroy our jobs, it can happen much earlier.

As scientists we need to reject and evict these misleading and false narrative people who try to hijack the industry with their political agenda, it has no place in science, this person should be ashamed of themselves and should exit the industry and stop spreading fake info and lies.

author: @jimstartup2729
text: AI is a tool that allows people that have little capability or understanding to perform tasks they are cognitively incapable of understanding. That goes for consequences. The scope for social modelling, influence and control is truly scary. If Facebook and Twitter can influence elections sufficiently already, then throwing AI into the mix at the hands of people with malign interests literally tells us this is practically the end of democracy and possibly the dawn if absolute chaos. The sheer scope of information AI can process and draw "simple to understand" conclusions from alone makes it hugely troublesome in a world that alread has a runaway problem of content control. These things are already processes we can no longer fully manage correctly as the scope is beyond human comprehension. If only people would be more reserved on this but.. people want to make money and are pushing it like a gold rush. Humanity on a global level is at severe risk here if not only based on the risk to our very global information base (the internet) being corrupted at a level we wont comprehend. All this at the hands of someone that in the end just needs to have an idea to be able to create things previously unattainable. its just too much power too fast for too many people for this not to be a disaster.

author: @mh60648
text: Side-note: Be aware that both the current technology used, for example, for wind energy and solar panels or not actually sustainable, and the term 'renewable' is regularly used to make it sound better (it's actually a bit of a scam). For example, to the uninformed crowd, a solar panel appears to us as less damaging to the environment, but for various reasons that have to do with the raw materials, the life-span, and what happens after its life-span, solar panels should not be called sustainable, or even renewable. We have not yet been able to exploit any kind of energy source in a truly safe, renewable, and sustainable way, even though some technologies are not directly emitting carbon themselves once they are functioning. Are we are not clever enough to invent a way to provide energy without destroying the planet? Do we need AI to invent it for us? No, we don't nee IA for that! We are perfectly capable of inventing it ourselves. But to invent it, we need the right environment, incentive, and (financial) freedom, all of which are not available within our current culture, economy, and financial system. In other words, we need to evolve away from the ego-driven competition-society we are currently maintaining for no other reason than that the ones who profit from it, are also the ones who decide for us. We need to learn how to work together, and that means we need to evolve and break free from certain restrictions of a paradigm that is falling apart, and focus on what is really important.

author: @amdenis
text: A lot of what she asserts is well supported, by generally, well over 99% of the energy/carbon costs are during training not during inference (end user usage). This assumes a baseline of google query vs GPT 4.x LLM query. We do need mire efficient ways to train AI, but AI has already come up with a new algorithm that dramatically reduces the cost/carbon impact of the highest non-AI use case: search/sort routines. Also, the current 10-fold increase in price/performance per year, coupled with the fact that ‚Äúwe have no moat, and either does Open AI‚Äù, means soon any kid in their bedroom, bad actor, small team from an adversarial country can engineer some thing far beyond today‚Äôs AI for 1/thousandth to 1/millionth the cost. What she has completely missed is that unlike Moores Law that takes about a lifetime to be over a million times more capable at the same price, AI will grow to that extent a couple times in about a decade. So, we are not ‚Äúall in it together and able to decide together where it goes‚Äù, as individuals with a few thousand dollars will be able to do things far beyond what a team with a billion could last year. And maybe more importantly, a very advanced future version of where we are at is only a few years away given the double exponential growth of AI.

author: @policani
text: With more energy-efficient models and consumer-grade AI specialty processors on the horizon, the environmental costs of employing generative AI to perform a task are significantly less than the relative costs of hiring a human to perform a task. When choosing between hiring a human and renting processor time to perform the same amount of work, the AI worker is far more environmentally friendly.

author: @policani
text: Often, I hear individuals with left-leaning views express concerns about unconscious bias against various communities. However, I‚Äôm reminded of Senator Blackburn‚Äôs recent experience where she was unable to get ChatGPT to write a favorable poem about Trump, while it readily produced one for Biden. This incident, along with several others, raises questions about the intentions of activists who advocate for more AI training in the name of trust and safety, but then set rules that may seem arbitrary. It‚Äôs seriously worth contemplating whether it‚Äôs worse for a society to suffer from accidental unconscious biases or intentional, consciously set biases that don‚Äôt take universally shared values into account. I think we can all agree that it‚Äôs good to avoid recipes containing chlorine gas, but when it comes to politicians, religious topics, moral arguments, etc., I don‚Äôt trust corporate trust and safety teams to act in the universal interests of their users.

author: @policani
text: Have you pondered the possibility of extreme leftist bias in AI models? For example, I recently attempted to use ChatGPT to develop a fantasy novel outline I wrote, however as I proceeded to refine my outline, I noticed that it was unnecessarily injecting themes of environmental stewardship or diversity as a strength into my outline. These are just a couple of instances where I found my writing experiment hindered due to the injection of someone else‚Äôs biases into my project. Despite the use of negative prompts, I was unable to eliminate these overarching concepts from my story outline.

author: @FairyWasabi
text: Ah, the looming spectre of AI, with its promises of a bright future and its not-so-subtle hints of potential doom. Sasha Luccioni, an AI ethics researcher, steps onto the TED stage to remind us that while AI might not be gearing up to terminate humanity a la Terminator, it's still not exactly the trustworthy robot friend we might hope for. Luccioni brings us back down to Earth (pun intended) by pointing out some very real and current concerns about AI. Forget about sci-fi scenarios of AI overlords; let's talk about the here and now. She dives into the environmental impact, highlighting how AI's insatiable hunger for data and computing power can leave quite the carbon footprint. It's like realising your friendly AI assistant might be secretly a carbon-spewing factory in disguise. But wait, there's more! Luccioni also shines a light on AI's less-than-stellar track record when it comes to copyright infringement. Picture AI as that kid in school who always copied someone else's homework but with the potential for much bigger consequences. From music to art to literature, AI's ability to churn out "original" works raises some serious questions about intellectual property. And let's not forget the delightful world of biased information. Luccioni doesn't hold back in pointing out how AI, with its algorithms and data sets, can unwittingly perpetuate and even amplify biases. It's like giving your well-meaning but slightly clueless friend the keys to the internet and hoping they won't mess things up too badly. But fear not, for Luccioni doesn't just leave us in a pit of AI-induced despair. She offers a glimmer of hope with practical solutions. Regulations, transparency, inclusivity‚Äîthese are the tools she presents to navigate our AI-filled future with a bit more confidence. So, here's to Sasha Luccioni, the voice of reason in the cacophony of AI hype. May her words serve as a wake-up call to the very real challenges we face in this AI-driven world. Let's regulate, let's be transparent, and let's ensure that our AI companions of the future are more Wall-E than Skynet. After all, it's not about fearing the robot apocalypse‚Äîit's about making sure we're the ones in control of the machines, not the other way around. Cheers to a future where AI is a helpful tool, not a cause for concern! ü•Çü§ñüí°

author: @mikahundin
text: - Sasha Luccioni, an AI researcher, starts her TED talk by recounting an unusual email she received from a stranger claiming her work in AI would lead to humanity's demise. This sets the stage for a discussion about the perception and reality of AI's dangers. - Luccioni acknowledges the widespread fascination with AI, ranging from its positive contributions like medical discoveries to its darker implications such as harmful chatbot interactions and biased AI meal planner suggestions. - The talk moves beyond speculative doomsday scenarios to focus on the present-day impacts of AI on society and the environment. Luccioni points out that AI is not isolated but interconnected with societal structures, leading to issues such as contributing to climate change, using data without consent, and perpetuating biases. - A major concern highlighted is the environmental cost of AI, particularly the significant energy consumption and carbon emissions associated with training large language models like Bloom. She stresses the importance of measuring and disclosing these environmental impacts and advocates for sustainability in AI development and deployment. - Additionally, Luccioni discusses issues of consent in data usage for AI training, citing examples of artists and authors whose work has been used without permission. She emphasizes the need for tools like "Have I Been Trained?" to provide transparency and accountability in data usage for AI training. - The talk also addresses biases inherent in AI systems, especially concerning race and gender. Luccioni shares examples of biased facial recognition systems and biased image generation models and introduces tools like the Stable Bias Explorer to help understand and mitigate biases in AI. - Overall, Luccioni concludes by advocating for collective action to address the current impacts of AI, stressing the importance of transparency, accessibility, and accountability in AI development and deployment. She emphasizes the need for informed choices, legislation, and governance to ensure that AI benefits society while minimizing its negative impacts.

author: @mikahundin
text: According to the speaker, Sasha Luccioni, AI is dangerous not solely due to future existential risks but because of its current tangible impacts on society and the environment. She emphasizes several reasons why AI is currently dangerous: 1. **Environmental Impact**: AI models, particularly large language models, consume vast amounts of energy and emit significant carbon dioxide during training. This contributes to climate change and environmental degradation. 2. **Data Usage Without Consent**: AI often uses data, including art and books, without the consent of the creators. This raises ethical concerns regarding intellectual property rights and fairness. 3. **Bias and Discrimination**: AI systems can perpetuate biases present in their training data, leading to discriminatory outcomes, especially against marginalized communities. This bias can manifest in various applications, such as facial recognition systems and image generation models. 4. **Privacy Concerns**: AI-powered systems collect and analyze large amounts of personal data, potentially infringing on individuals' privacy rights and leading to surveillance concerns. 5. **Automation and Job Displacement**: AI's automation capabilities have the potential to displace jobs and disrupt entire industries, leading to economic challenges and social inequalities. Overall, Luccioni argues that focusing solely on future existential risks detracts from addressing the current tangible impacts of AI. She advocates for increased transparency, accountability, and the development of tools to measure and mitigate these impacts to ensure that AI technology is deployed responsibly.

author: @rontarrant
text: The first thing that has to be done in order for people to better understand AI is to _change the name._ It's not intelligent. It can't combine known data to come up with _new_ data. That's the first mark of intelligent, taking what is known and extrapolating a new idea. Machines can't do that, have _never_ been able to do that, and never _will_ do that. Why? Because that requires sentience and for something to be sentient there needs to be an element beyond the physical machinery, a non-corporeal entity. And since science doesn't accept the existence of such things (because they can't be measured and therefore couldn't possibly exist) how could scientists ever create one, let alone instill it into a machine?
